comments:
I believe this is while trying to connect to dev.eclipse.org. 
  
!SESSION 2005-10-21 08:32:47.887  
-----------------------------------------------  
eclipse.buildId=I20051018-0932  
java.version=1.5.0_04  
java.vendor=Sun Microsystems Inc.  
BootLoader constants: OS=linux, ARCH=x86, WS=gtk, NL=en_US  
Command-line arguments:  -os linux -ws gtk -arch x86  
-data /home/dpollock/Source/Eclipse/Workspaces/HEAD  
  
!ENTRY org.eclipse.team.cvs.core 4 -10 2005-10-21 10:05:28.439  
!MESSAGE The server reported an error: No space left on device  
!SUBENTRY 1 org.eclipse.team.cvs.core 4 -10 2005-10-21 10:05:28.439  
!MESSAGE The server reported an error: No space left on device  
.log (END)

There is no apparent issue with a lack of disk space on dev, and I cannot locate
 the path '/home/dpollock/Source/Eclipse/Workspaces/Head'. So my guess is that
it is a local thing.

-M.

I got this as well when trying to commit and it is definitely a server issue. 
The server message I got was:

cannot create_adm_p /tmp/cvs-serv2012/src/org/eclipse/team/ui/mapping

It seems to be a transitive thing as I was able to commit shortly after that.

Oh, come on Mr. Webmaster, sir.  You're not getting off that easily.  :) 
 
I checked my box for disk space issues before filing this bug.  Plus the 
message is clearly: "The server reported an error"

I just had a commit fail with the following log entry (in Eclipse).  Upgrading 
to BLOCKER.

Ok, with the path given in Michaels comment I took a look at our servers and
indeed on one of them the /tmp directory was full due to a tomcat crash, which
would explain the error. I have restarted that server( which was the cause of
Dougs hangup ) and cleaned out the /tmp directory. So things should be back to
something resembling normal now.

I have to ask a really stupid question: is the cvs repository you are using set
to dev.eclipse.org? Or is it a specific IP?

Anyway please try it again and let me know if it is still failing.

If things are still broken, let me know.

-M,

Tomcat seems to be the issue here -- and it will happen again.  When Tomcay
dies, it dumps large core files to /tmp.

Denis to look into one of the following:

1. Either Tomcat is removed from the cluster so it doesn't affect critical services

2. Tomcat be configured to dump its cores elsewhere.

D.

The issue seems to be with mod_jk.

Since bypassing mod_jk with simple ProxyPass directives the problem hasn't
reoccurred.

Denis to remove mod_jk altogether and configure apps to use ProxyPass.

D.

Closing.  I removed all that mod_jk crap.

D.

traces.message: Timeout while reading from input stream
